diagnoses.name: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)
screening: Men 65-75 who ever smoked: one-time abdominal US
Consider in women >65 with smoking/family history

repair_indications: AAA ≥5.5 cm in men, ≥5.0 cm in women
Rapid expansion >0.5 cm in 6 mo or >1 cm in 1 yr
repair_options: Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) - preferred if suitable anatomy
Open repair - if unsuitable anatomy or younger/low-risk patients

elective_surgery: Do not repair small asymptomatic AAAs (<5.0-5.5 cm) unless rapid growth

follow_up: Continue smoking cessation, statin, antiplatelet, BP control

instructions: Report sudden back/abdominal pain or syncope (rupture warning)

diagnoses.name: Acute Coronary Syndrome (UA/NSTEMI/STEMI)

clinical_triggers.notes: Atypical presentation common in women, elderly, diabetics.

red_flags: Severe LV dysfunction or acute heart failure
Recurrent/persistent rest angina despite intensive therapy

ecg.timing: Obtain immediately and repeat serially (e.g., q10 min with ongoing symptoms)
ecg.stemi_definition: ST elevation in ≥2 contiguous leads (per local criteria); new LBBB concerning for MI in context of ischemia
ecg.unstable_angina_nstemi: Ischemic changes: ST depression ≥0.5 mm and/or T-wave inversion

labs.serial_strategy: Repeat troponin at 0 and 1-3 hours per protocol; consider 6-12h in high-risk cases
labs.reinfarction: Consider reinfarction if troponin rises >20% from prior falling value

imaging: CXR if alternative diagnosis or heart failure suspected

all_patients_initial: Aspirin (chewed) loading dose
P2Y12 inhibitor load (ticagrelor, clopidogrel, prasugrel) per strategy
Anticoagulation (heparin/fondaparinux per renal function/strategy)
High-intensity statin
Beta-blocker if no contraindications
Nitrates for pain relief (avoid in RV infarct or recent PDE-5 inhibitor use)
Oxygen ONLY if hypoxic

fibrinolysis.when: If PCI unavailable within goal time and symptom onset <12h

strategy: TIMI 0-2: medical therapy + stress testing if asymptomatic; abnormal test → angiography

right_ventricle_infarct_considerations: Avoid nitrates to prevent severe hypotension (preload dependent)
post_mi_hospital_course: Continuous rhythm monitoring (common early cause of death: VT/VF)

mandatory_meds_core: P2Y12 inhibitor for 12 months if PCI/stent (clopidogrel 75 mg daily or ticagrelor 90 mg BID; prasugrel per indications)
High-intensity statin (atorvastatin 40-80 mg or rosuvastatin 20-40 mg)
ACEi/ARB/ARNI if EF ≤40% or other indications
SL nitroglycerin 0.4 mg PRN chest pain (up to 3 doses)
Gastric protection (e.g., pantoprazole) with DAPT if GI risk
follow_up: Risk-factor optimization (lipids, BP, DM, smoking cessation)

practical_applications_cis: P2Y12 oral load + full-dose aspirin, then ASA 81 mg daily
Keep NPO for LHC when indicated; complete angiogram checklist
Add nitrates for chest pain relief; prefer sublingual over topical for assessment
Order high-intensity statin; add A1c and fasting lipid panel
notes: Nitrates contraindicated in RV infarct or recent phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor use
Cocaine-associated MI: treat similarly but avoid beta-blockers; use benzodiazepines

sections: ACS overview, diagnostics, treatment, thrombolytics, TIMI, discharge meds, practical applications

signs_any: 6 P's: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesia, Paralysis, Poikilothermia

delay: Do not delay revascularization for imaging if limb immediately threatened

instructions: Report recurrent limb pain, numbness, weakness

symptoms_any: Severe abdominal pain out of proportion to exam

delay: Do not delay operative intervention if peritonitis or shock

diagnoses.name: Acute Pericarditis

symptoms_any: Sharp, pleuritic chest pain improved by sitting forward
signs_any: Diffuse ST elevation with PR depression (ECG)

initial_tests: CXR (may be normal or show enlarged silhouette if large effusion)
Blood cultures if febrile; TB/autoimmune/other workup as indicated

all_patients_initial: NSAIDs (ibuprofen, indomethacin, high-dose aspirin) for 1-2 weeks with taper
Colchicine for 3 months to reduce recurrence
Glucocorticoids only if refractory or specific indication (autoimmune, uremia, pregnancy)

follow_up: Repeat echo if effusion suspected or symptoms persist

instructions: Report worsening chest pain, dyspnea, or syncope (tamponade)

diagnoses.name: Aortic Dissection
classification: Stanford A: involves ascending aorta (surgical emergency)
Stanford B: confined to descending (medical unless complications)

initial: Add vasodilator (nicardipine, nitroprusside) for SBP <120 if needed
definitive: Type B: medical management unless rupture, malperfusion, aneurysmal expansion - then endovascular stent graft

beta_blocker_monotherapy: Avoid vasodilator without β-blocker (reflex tachycardia worsens dissection)

follow_up: Serial imaging (CTA/MRA at 1, 3, 6, 12 mo, then annually)

instructions: Immediate ED evaluation for recurrent chest/back pain or neuro deficits

diagnoses.name: Aortic Regurgitation

signs_any: Diastolic blowing murmur at left sternal border
De Musset's head bobbing, Quincke's pulse (severe chronic AR)

initial_tests: Transthoracic echo (severity, LV size/function, root/ascending aorta)
BNP for prognostic info in chronic AR

all_patients_initial: Afterload reduction (ACEi/ARB, nifedipine) may improve symptoms in severe AR if not surgical candidate
Treat underlying causes (syphilis, endocarditis, aortic root disease, etc.)
definitive: Symptomatic severe AR or LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF ≤50%): AVR (surgical preferred)
Asymptomatic severe AR with progressive LV dilation: AVR

beta_blockers: Avoid in isolated severe AR - prolongs diastole and worsens regurgitant volume

follow_up: Echo surveillance: mild q3-5y, moderate q1-2y, severe q6-12mo

instructions: Monitor for new dyspnea, chest pain, palpitations

diagnoses.name: Aortic Stenosis

signs_any: Harsh, late-peaking systolic ejection murmur at RUSB radiating to carotids

initial_tests: Transthoracic echo (valve area, mean gradient, jet velocity, LV function)

echo_criteria: Severe AS: Vmax ≥4.0 m/s or mean gradient ≥40 mmHg or valve area ≤1.0 cm²
Low-flow/low-gradient AS: consider dobutamine stress echo or CT calcium scoring

all_patients_initial: Medical therapy does not halt progression; manage comorbidities (HTN, lipids)
Avoid hypotension and excessive preload reduction
definitive: Symptomatic severe AS or LVEF <50%: valve replacement (SAVR or TAVR)
Asymptomatic severe AS with very severe Vmax, rapid progression, or abnormal exercise test: consider intervention
periop: Cardiology/heart-team evaluation for TAVR vs SAVR based on age, anatomy, surgical risk

afterload_reduction: Use vasodilators cautiously; avoid precipitous BP drops
nitrates: Use with caution if preload dependent; monitor for hypotension

follow_up: Echo surveillance: mild q3-5y, moderate q1-2y, severe q6-12mo or sooner if symptoms change

instructions: Educate on red-flag symptoms (syncope, angina, dyspnea) and prompt evaluation
Endocarditis prophylaxis only for high-risk prosthetic valve patients
follow_up: Valve clinic/cardiology follow-up per severity; post-TAVR/SAVR protocols as applicable

diagnoses.name: Atrial Fibrillation / Flutter
initial_tests: 12‑lead ECG (irregularly irregular rhythm, absent P waves)
TSH, BMP/Mg, CBC; consider troponin if ischemia suspected
Echocardiogram (structure, LA size, valves, LV function)

risk_scoring.bleeding_risk: HAS‑BLED for bleeding risk (do not use to withhold OAC outright)

acute: Stable: rate control (β‑blocker or diltiazem/verapamil); consider digoxin if hypotension/HFrEF
Anticoagulation strategy based on CHA₂DS₂‑VASc and duration of AF
rhythm_control: Electrical cardioversion if appropriate (consider TEE to exclude LAA thrombus if >48h or unknown)
Antiarrhythmics in selected patients (amiodarone, dofetilide, flecainide/propafenone if no structural heart disease)
Catheter ablation for symptomatic AF refractory or intolerant to AADs
rate_control: β‑blocker or non‑DHP CCB (verapamil/diltiazem) for most patients
Add digoxin in HFrEF or low BP limiting other agents
anticoagulation: DOAC preferred over warfarin in eligible patients
Peri‑cardioversion anticoagulation per guideline (≥3 weeks before and 4 weeks after if >48h or unknown duration)

class_ic: Avoid in structural heart disease or CAD (proarrhythmia)

instructions: Stroke prevention plan documented (OAC if indicated)
Education on rate/rhythm meds and when to seek care (worsening palpitations, syncope, chest pain)
follow_up: Cardiology EP follow‑up; consider sleep apnea evaluation and risk factor modification (weight loss, ETOH moderation)

diagnoses.name: Atrial Flutter

signs_any: ECG: sawtooth flutter waves (typically 300 bpm atrial rate)
Ventricular response often ~150 bpm if 2:1 conduction
Tachycardia, irregular pulse if variable block

initial_tests: Echo (assess structural disease, LA size, LV function)

acute: Rate control with β-blocker or nondihydropyridine CCB
Electrical cardioversion if unstable or refractory
long_term: Catheter ablation (cavotricuspid isthmus ablation) - high success, first-line definitive therapy

follow_up: Cardiology/EP follow-up, especially if considering ablation

diagnoses.name: Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)

signs_any: Systolic ejection murmur at LUSB (↑ flow across pulmonic valve)

initial_tests: Echo with bubble study (diagnosis, shunt size/direction)
TEE for small or sinus venosus ASD

indications_for_closure: ASD with RA/RV enlargement or significant shunt (Qp:Qs >1.5)
closure_options: Percutaneous device closure if suitable anatomy
Surgical closure if not suitable for device

follow_up: Monitor for AF, RV dysfunction, pulmonary HTN in adulthood

instructions: Endocarditis prophylaxis not routinely indicated except 6 mo post-device closure
Report new palpitations, syncope, or dyspnea
follow_up: Cardiology follow-up, lifelong in some cases

diagnoses.name: Bradyarrhythmias (Sinus Node Dysfunction & AV Block)

signs_any: ECG: sinus pauses, sinus bradycardia <50 bpm
ECG: AV block (Mobitz I, Mobitz II, 3rd degree)

initial_tests: Labs (TSH, electrolytes, drug levels e.g. digoxin)

long_term: Permanent pacemaker for symptomatic sinus node dysfunction
Pacemaker for Mobitz II or complete heart block regardless of symptoms

asymptomatic: No pacing for asymptomatic sinus bradycardia or Mobitz I

follow_up: Monitor for progression in conduction disease

instructions: Medication adherence; avoid AV nodal blockers if worsening bradycardia

diagnoses.name: Cardiac Arrest / Sudden Cardiac Death
initial_tests: ECG rhythm identification (VF, pulseless VT, PEA, asystole)

pea_asystole: CPR, epinephrine, treat reversible causes (Hs & Ts)

instructions: Family counseling, ICD consideration if appropriate

intervention: Surgical vein stripping for severe/refractory disease

instructions: Skin care with emollients, wound care if ulcers
follow_up: Vascular follow-up; wound care clinic if ulcers present

diagnoses.name: Constrictive Pericarditis
initial_tests: Echo (septal bounce, respiratory ventricular interdependence, thickened pericardium)

definitive: Pericardiectomy for symptomatic patients with chronic constriction

follow_up: Monitor for worsening right-sided HF symptoms
Consider referral for surgical pericardiectomy evaluation

instructions: Daily weight, monitor edema and ascites
Adherence to low-sodium diet and diuretics

signs_any: Calf swelling >3 cm vs other leg

anticoagulation: DOAC (apixaban, rivaroxaban) preferred if not contraindicated
LMWH/warfarin if DOAC not suitable (cancer, pregnancy special considerations)
duration: Unprovoked: ≥3 months, consider indefinite if low bleeding risk
Cancer-associated: at least 3-6 months, often longer

anticoagulation: Active bleeding, high bleeding risk - consider IVC filter if acute proximal DVT

instructions: Leg elevation, compression stockings if chronic symptoms

diagnoses.name: Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM)
initial_tests: Echo (dilated LV, reduced EF, global hypokinesis)
Labs (BNP, troponin, TSH, iron studies, viral/autoimmune workup as indicated)
Consider cardiac MRI for fibrosis/infiltrative disease

all_patients_initial: Guideline-directed HF therapy (ARNI/ACEi/ARB, β-blocker, MRA, SGLT2i)
Diuretics for volume overload
ICD for EF ≤35% after 3 mo optimal therapy
CRT if EF ≤35% with LBBB and QRS ≥150 ms

instructions: Call for rapid weight gain, worsening dyspnea/edema

diagnoses.name: Essential Hypertension

signs_any: Elevated office BP (≥130/80 per guideline context)

initial_tests: Confirm with out-of-office BP (home/ambulatory) when feasible
ECG (LVH, prior MI) ± Echo if indicated

risk_scoring.use: Guides intensity of BP and lipid therapy; lifestyle vs meds

all_patients_initial: Lifestyle: weight loss, DASH diet, salt restriction, exercise, alcohol moderation, avoid NSAIDs
First-line meds (non-Black, no CKD): thiazide (chlorthalidone), ACEi/ARB, or CCB
CKD/proteinuria: ACEi/ARB preferred
Black patients (without CKD): thiazide or CCB preferred
Diabetes: ACEi/ARB reasonable; consider SGLT2i/GLP-1 RA for CV benefit (comorbidity management)
targets: Typical goal <130/80 mmHg for most adults (individualize)

follow_up: Titrate every 2-4 weeks until at goal
Monitor K+/Cr after starting ACEi/ARB or diuretics
notes: Screen for secondary causes if resistant HTN, abrupt onset, hypokalemia, or young age at diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure with Preserved EF (HFpEF)
red_flags: Atrial fibrillation with RVR causing hemodynamic compromise
Chest pain with dynamic ECG changes (suspect ACS)
initial_tests: BNP or NT‑proBNP (often elevated but lower than HFrEF for similar symptoms)
Transthoracic echocardiogram (diastolic function, LA size, LV mass, RV/pulmonary pressures)
CBC, CMP, Mg, TSH, fasting glucose/A1c, lipids
pathophysiology_notes: Symptoms due to impaired relaxation/compliance and increased filling pressures.
Often associated with age, female sex, hypertension, obesity, diabetes, CKD, AF.

foundations: Aggressive treatment of comorbidities: hypertension, obesity, diabetes, CKD, AF, OSA
Exercise training / cardiac rehab improves functional capacity
bp_and_risk: ACEi/ARB/ARNI or CCB per BP and tolerance
MRA (spironolactone) may reduce HF hospitalizations in selected patients
rate_rhythm: Atrial fibrillation management (rate/rhythm control) and anticoagulation per CHA₂DS₂‑VASc
Heart rate control to allow diastolic filling; avoid excessive tachycardia
pulmonary_hypertension: Manage underlying left‑sided filling pressures; PAH‑specific drugs not beneficial unless Group 1 PAH

contraindications: Avoid routine nitrates for HFpEF symptom relief (no benefit)
Use caution with aggressive preload reduction; patients are preload sensitive
follow_up: Optimize comorbidity control; periodic reassessment of diastolic parameters
Titrate diuretics to weight and symptoms; monitor renal function and electrolytes
Lifestyle and exercise prescription; weight loss for obesity

medications: SGLT2 inhibitor if not contraindicated; consider MRA in appropriate patients
instructions: Sleep apnea evaluation if suspected; exercise program referral
follow_up: Primary cardiology follow‑up within 2-4 weeks; earlier if recent decompensation

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure with Reduced EF (HFrEF)
red_flags: Refractory hypoxemia or severe respiratory distress
Worsening renal failure, hyperkalemia, or hyponatremia
Chest pain with dynamic ECG changes (suspect ACS)
initial_tests: Iron studies (if anemia or suspected deficiency)

foundation: ARNI (sacubitril/valsartan preferred) OR ACEi/ARB if ARNI not feasible
gdmt.diuretics: Loop diuretic (e.g., furosemide, bumetanide) titrated to euvolemia; consider thiazide add‑on for diuretic resistance
add_ons: Ivabradine (sinus rhythm, HR ≥70 bpm on max β‑blocker, EF ≤35%)
Hydralazine/Isosorbide dinitrate (African ancestry or ACEi/ARB intolerance)
Vericiguat (selected high‑risk patients with recent decompensation)
Digoxin (rate control in AF or symptoms despite GDMT; narrow TI)
device_considerations: ICD: EF ≤35% despite ≥3 months GDMT and good functional status
CRT: LBBB with QRS ≥150 ms, EF ≤35%, persistent symptoms on GDMT
Consider advanced therapies (LVAD, transplant) for refractory Stage D
contraindications: ACEi/ARB/ARNI: history of angioedema, pregnancy, severe hyperkalemia
MRA: K+ >5.0 mEq/L or severe renal dysfunction
SGLT2i: history of DKA; hold during severe illness or procedures
β‑blocker: acute decompensation with shock/pulmonary edema (initiate after stabilization)

inpatient_management: Assess profile: warm/dry vs warm/wet vs cold/wet; tailor diuretics and vasodilators/inotropes accordingly
IV loop diuretics (1-2× home PO dose) with strict I/O, daily weights
Vasodilators (e.g., IV nitroglycerin) if hypertensive and congested
Inotropes (dobutamine/milrinone) for cardiogenic shock or hypoperfusion
Identify and treat precipitants: ACS, arrhythmia, infection, anemia, non‑adherence, high salt/fluid intake
follow_up: Up‑titrate GDMT every 2-4 weeks toward target doses as tolerated
Reassess BMP/K+ within 1-2 weeks after initiating or uptitrating RAAS/MRA
Repeat TTE 3-6 months after GDMT optimization
Low‑sodium diet, fluid guidance, daily weights; action plan for rapid weight gain
Early post‑discharge follow‑up within 7 days; consider HF disease management program

medications: Ensure 4‑pillar GDMT started or planned (ARNI/ACE/ARB, β‑blocker, MRA, SGLT2i)
Loop diuretic with clear dose/goal and PRN plan
Vaccinations and guideline lipid/BP therapy as indicated
instructions: Daily weights; call if +2-3 lb in 24h or +5 lb in a week
Sodium restriction (e.g., 2 g/day) and individualized fluid guidance
Medication adherence, avoid NSAIDs, alcohol moderation, smoking cessation
follow_up: Cardiology or HF clinic in 3-7 days post‑discharge

notes: Target doses should be individualized to BP, renal function, and potassium.
Consider iron repletion in iron deficiency (IV preferred in symptomatic HF).

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Urgency / Emergency

signs_any: Evidence of acute end-organ damage suggests **Emergency** (e.g., encephalopathy, stroke, ACS, AHF, aortic dissection, AKI, eclampsia)

initial_tests: Focused exam for end-organ damage (neuro, cardio-pulm)
CXR if pulmonary edema; Head CT if neuro deficits; Fundoscopy if concern for retinal hemorrhages

all_patients_initial: Differentiate **Urgency** (no end-organ damage) vs **Emergency** (with damage)
Urgency: oral agents, gradual reduction over 24-48h, close follow-up
Emergency: ICU, IV meds; lower MAP ~10-20% in first hour, then additional 5-15% over next 23h (avoid rapid over-correction)
special_cases: Aortic dissection: reduce HR/BP rapidly with β-blocker + vasodilator (SBP <120, HR <60)
Ischemic stroke: follow thrombolysis/EVT BP thresholds
Preeclampsia/eclampsia: labetalol, hydralazine, or nifedipine; magnesium for seizure prophylaxis

rapid_lowering: Avoid precipitous BP drops that risk cerebral/coronary ischemia

follow_up: Close outpatient follow-up within days after urgency; ensure long-term regimen optimization

diagnoses.name: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

signs_any: Harsh systolic murmur at LSB/apex, ↑ with Valsalva, ↓ with squatting

initial_tests: Echo (asymmetric septal hypertrophy, systolic anterior motion of mitral valve, dynamic LVOT gradient)

all_patients_initial: β-blockers (first-line) or non-DHP CCBs (verapamil, diltiazem)
Avoid dehydration, excessive exertion, vasodilators, diuretics (↓ preload)
ICD if prior cardiac arrest, sustained VT, or high-risk features
advanced: Septal reduction (surgical myectomy or alcohol ablation) if refractory symptoms with gradient

vasodilators: Avoid nitrates, ACEi/ARB, diuretics in obstructive HCM - worsen gradient

follow_up: Annual echo if symptomatic or every 1-2y if stable

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis

signs_any: New murmur or changing regurgitant murmur
Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, Roth spots

initial_tests: Echo (TTE initial, TEE more sensitive for vegetations/abscess)

empiric: IV vancomycin ± cefepime until cultures available
definitive: Targeted IV antibiotics for 4-6 weeks based on organism
Surgery if heart failure, uncontrolled infection, large vegetations with emboli, abscess

anticoagulation: Avoid starting anticoagulation in acute IE with CNS emboli (risk of hemorrhage)

follow_up: Monitor renal function, drug levels (aminoglycosides, vancomycin)

instructions: Adherence to prolonged IV antibiotic therapy (often via PICC)
Dental hygiene to reduce recurrence risk

diagnoses.name: Long QT Syndrome (LQTS)

signs_any: ECG: prolonged QT interval (QTc >470 ms women, >450 ms men)

initial_tests: Family history, genetic testing if congenital LQTS suspected

general: Avoid QT-prolonging drugs (macrolides, fluoroquinolones, antiarrhythmics, antipsychotics, methadone, etc.)
long_term: ICD if history of cardiac arrest, recurrent syncope/VT despite β-blocker
Left cardiac sympathetic denervation in refractory cases
torsades: Overdrive pacing or isoproterenol if bradycardic

diagnoses.name: Microvascular Angina (Cardiac Syndrome X)

symptoms_any: Angina-like chest pain, often prolonged and not always exertional
signs_any: Normal or near-normal coronaries on angiography

initial_tests: Stress testing (may be positive for ischemia)
Coronary flow reserve testing (abnormal in microvascular angina)

all_patients_initial: Antianginal therapy: β-blockers, CCBs, nitrates (variable efficacy)
Risk factor modification (HTN, DM, lipids, obesity)
ACEi/ARB and statins may improve endothelial function

instructions: Adherence to medications for angina and risk factor control
Seek urgent care for worsening or new typical angina symptoms

diagnoses.name: Mitral Regurgitation

signs_any: Holosystolic murmur at apex radiating to axilla
Acute severe MR: pulmonary edema, soft/absent murmur

initial_tests: Transthoracic echo (jet severity, LA/LV size, function, mechanism)
TEE if needed for mechanism/surgical planning

all_patients_initial: Treat HTN, AF, and heart failure symptoms
Afterload reduction (ACEi/ARB, vasodilators) in acute or symptomatic MR if not immediately surgical
definitive: Symptomatic severe MR or LVEF ≤60% or LVESD ≥40 mm → mitral surgery (repair preferred over replacement)
Acute severe MR (papillary rupture, chordal rupture, endocarditis): urgent surgery
device: MitraClip (TEER) for selected patients not surgical candidates

vasodilators: Use cautiously in preload-dependent patients with acute MR and hypotension

follow_up: Echo surveillance: mild q3-5y, moderate q1-2y, severe q6-12mo

instructions: Report new or worsening dyspnea, edema, or palpitations
Maintain dental hygiene to reduce endocarditis risk

diagnoses.name: Mitral Stenosis

signs_any: Diastolic rumble at apex with opening snap
Signs of pulmonary HTN (loud P2, RV heave)

initial_tests: Transthoracic echo (valve area, mean gradient, LA size, pulmonary pressures)

all_patients_initial: Diuretics for pulmonary congestion
Rate control (β-blocker, diltiazem, digoxin) if AF
Anticoagulation if AF, prior embolism, or LA thrombus
intervention: Percutaneous balloon mitral valvotomy if suitable anatomy
Surgical repair/replacement if not suitable or concurrent valve disease

pregnancy: Careful management; balloon valvotomy considered if severe symptoms

instructions: Report new-onset dyspnea, palpitations, or hemoptysis
Endocarditis prophylaxis only in select prosthetic/high-risk cases
follow_up: Cardiology follow-up per severity and rhythm status

diagnoses.name: Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)

symptoms_any: Large PDA: HF, poor growth, frequent respiratory infections

initial_tests: CXR (↑ pulmonary vascularity, cardiomegaly if large)

pharmacologic: Indomethacin/ibuprofen to close PDA in preterm neonates

follow_up: Monitor for pulmonary HTN if untreated large PDA

instructions: Endocarditis prophylaxis for 6 mo after closure

diagnoses.name: Pericardial Effusion / Tamponade

signs_any: Muffled heart sounds, JVD, hypotension (Beck's triad)

initial_tests: Echo (effusion size, diastolic chamber collapse, IVC plethora)
CXR (enlarged cardiac silhouette if large effusion)

stable: Treat underlying cause (infection, malignancy, autoimmune, uremia)
Serial echo monitoring if no tamponade physiology
tamponade: Volume resuscitation and pressors as temporizing measure

follow_up: Monitor for recurrence depending on etiology

instructions: Report syncope, hypotension, or worsening dyspnea immediately
follow_up: Cardiology follow-up; oncology/rheum/nephrology if secondary cause

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD)

symptoms_any: Claudication (exertional leg pain relieved by rest)

initial_tests: Toe-brachial index for diabetics or non-compressible vessels
Exercise ABI if symptoms and normal resting ABI
Duplex ultrasound for anatomic assessment; CTA/MRA when planning revascularization

all_patients_initial: Smoking cessation
Supervised exercise therapy program
High-intensity statin
Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin or clopidogrel)
Optimize BP, diabetes; consider SGLT2i/GLP-1 RA for CV benefit in DM
claudication_pharmacotherapy: Cilostazol improves walking distance (avoid in HFrEF)
revascularization: Endovascular or surgical revascularization for lifestyle-limiting claudication refractory to therapy or critical limb-threatening ischemia

follow_up: Foot care education, wound surveillance in high-risk patients
ABI surveillance after revascularization per protocol

instructions: Adherence to exercise therapy and medications
follow_up: Vascular/cardiology follow-up; wound care as needed

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma / Paraganglioma
initial_tests: MIBG or PET for metastatic/extra-adrenal disease

preop: Then add β-blocker after α-blockade if tachycardia

beta_blocker_monotherapy: Never start β-blocker before α-blocker - risk hypertensive crisis

follow_up: Endocrinology follow-up, genetic counseling for familial cases

diagnoses.name: Primary Aldosteronism
initial_tests: Plasma aldosterone concentration (PAC) / plasma renin activity (PRA) ratio (screening)
Confirmatory tests: saline suppression, oral salt loading, fludrocortisone suppression
Adrenal CT to localize adenoma vs hyperplasia
Adrenal vein sampling if surgery considered

diagnoses.name: Pulmonary Embolism (PE)
initial_tests: Echo for RV strain if massive/submassive

massive_pe: Systemic thrombolysis (alteplase) if shock/hemodynamic collapse and no contraindications
Catheter-directed thrombolysis or surgical embolectomy if thrombolysis contraindicated/failed
submassive_pe: Thrombolysis considered if worsening RV dysfunction or clinical decline

thrombolysis: Recent major surgery, hemorrhagic stroke, active bleeding

follow_up: Hematology/pulmonology follow-up; duration based on provoked vs unprovoked

diagnoses.name: Pulmonary Hypertension
initial_tests: CT chest, V/Q scan for cause

specific: Endothelin receptor antagonists, PDE5 inhibitors, prostacyclin analogs

diagnoses.name: Pulmonic Valve Disease

signs_any: Pulmonic stenosis: systolic ejection murmur at LUSB radiating to back
Pulmonic regurgitation: diastolic decrescendo murmur (Graham Steell if due to pulmonary HTN)

initial_tests: Transthoracic echo (valve morphology, gradients, regurgitant jet, RV size/function)

pulmonic_stenosis: Balloon valvuloplasty for symptomatic severe PS (or asymptomatic severe with RV dysfunction)
Surgery if not suitable for balloon or with other lesions
pulmonic_regurgitation: Valve replacement if severe PR with RV dilation/dysfunction and symptoms

follow_up: Serial echo for moderate/severe lesions, RV size/function monitoring

instructions: Maintain dental hygiene (endocarditis risk if prosthetic valve)
follow_up: Cardiology/congenital specialist follow-up depending on etiology

diagnoses.name: Renal Artery Stenosis (RAS)
initial_tests: Renal angiography (gold standard, usually for intervention)

medical: Statins, antiplatelets, BP control, smoking cessation
intervention: Angioplasty ± stent in select patients (recurrent flash pulmonary edema, refractory HTN, progressive renal failure)

instructions: Monitor BP and kidney function regularly

diagnoses.name: Restrictive Cardiomyopathy (RCM)
initial_tests: Echo (normal LV size, biatrial enlargement, impaired diastolic filling, normal/small LV cavity)
BNP, iron studies, SPEP/UPEP (amyloidosis), genetic testing if indicated

all_patients_initial: Treat underlying cause (amyloidosis, hemochromatosis, sarcoidosis)
Diuretics for volume management (cautious)
Rate/rhythm control for AF, anticoagulation
Advanced therapies (transplant) if refractory

follow_up: Cardiology follow-up; specialty clinics if infiltrative disease

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Heart Disease

signs_any: New murmur of MR or MS

initial_tests: Throat culture or rapid strep test (initial infection)
Jones Criteria for diagnosis (2 major or 1 major + 2 minor)

acute: Penicillin (or erythromycin if allergic) for GAS eradication
long_term: Secondary prophylaxis with IM benzathine penicillin every 3-4 weeks (duration depends on severity, often 10+ years)
Valve repair/replacement for severe chronic MR/MS

follow_up: Monitor for progression to valvular disease (esp. MS, MR)

instructions: Report new dyspnea, palpitations, or edema
follow_up: Cardiology follow-up; infectious disease if recurrent strep

diagnoses.name: Stable (Chronic) Angina Pectoris

symptoms_any: Exertional chest pressure or discomfort, relieved by rest or nitroglycerin
May radiate to arm, neck, jaw
signs_any: Possible signs of CAD (bruits, HF signs if advanced)

initial_tests: Resting ECG (often normal, may show old MI or nonspecific changes)
Exercise treadmill test (first-line if able to exercise)
Stress imaging (echo or nuclear) if baseline ECG abnormal or unable to exercise
Coronary CT angiography or invasive coronary angiography for diagnosis/therapy if indicated

antianginal: Long-acting nitrates or CCBs if β-blocker contraindicated or uncontrolled
secondary_prevention: ACEi/ARB if HTN, DM, CKD, LV dysfunction
Lifestyle: smoking cessation, diet, exercise, weight management
revascularization: Consider PCI or CABG for refractory angina or high-risk anatomy

follow_up: Monitor symptom frequency, tolerance to meds

instructions: Carry nitroglycerin at all times, use for chest pain episodes
Call EMS if pain >5 minutes or not relieved by nitroglycerin
follow_up: Cardiology follow-up; repeat stress testing if symptoms worsen

stable: IV β-blocker or diltiazem if refractory
long_term: Catheter ablation for recurrent symptomatic SVT
β-blockers or nondihydropyridine CCBs as alternatives if not ablation candidate

wpw_af: Avoid AV nodal blockers (β-blocker, diltiazem, digoxin) if AF with WPW

instructions: Avoid stimulants (caffeine, sympathomimetics) that trigger SVT
Seek urgent care if episodes prolonged or associated with syncope

signs_any: Normal between episodes unless underlying cardiac/neuro cause

diagnoses.name: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

signs_any: Squatting behavior in children (↑ SVR reduces shunt)

initial_tests: Echo (VSD, RVOT obstruction, overriding aorta, RVH)

acute_tet_spell: Oxygen, knee-chest position, morphine, β-blocker (propranolol), IV fluids
definitive: Surgical repair in infancy (VSD closure + relieve RVOT obstruction)

follow_up: Monitor for residual RVOT obstruction, pulmonary regurgitation, arrhythmias, RV dysfunction

instructions: Endocarditis prophylaxis if prosthetic material used

signs_any: Polymorphic VT with twisting QRS axis, prolonged QT

acute: Overdrive pacing or isoproterenol if bradycardic

diagnoses.name: Tricuspid Regurgitation

signs_any: Holosystolic murmur at lower left sternal border, ↑ with inspiration (Carvallo sign)
Jugular venous distension with prominent v waves

initial_tests: Transthoracic echo (severity, RV size/function, annular dilation, pulmonary pressures)

all_patients_initial: Treat underlying cause (pulmonary HTN, left-sided heart disease, endocarditis, congenital)
Diuretics for volume overload
intervention: Surgical repair/replacement if severe symptomatic TR or undergoing left-sided surgery
Transcatheter options emerging for high-risk surgical candidates

follow_up: Serial echo based on severity and RV function

instructions: Monitor for worsening edema, ascites, fatigue
follow_up: Cardiology follow-up; consider advanced therapies if refractory symptoms

diagnoses.name: Variant (Prinzmetal) Angina

symptoms_any: Rest angina, often nocturnal or early morning
Episodes not clearly related to exertion
signs_any: Transient ST elevation during pain episodes

initial_tests: Resting ECG during episode (transient ST elevation)
Coronary angiography (often normal or mild CAD, may show spasm with provocation)

all_patients_initial: CCBs (diltiazem, amlodipine, verapamil)
Long-acting nitrates

follow_up: Monitor angina episodes, adjust CCB/nitrate therapy

diagnoses.name: Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)

symptoms_any: Large VSD: HF symptoms in infancy (tachypnea, poor feeding, FTT)
signs_any: Large VSD: signs of CHF, pulmonary HTN

initial_tests: Echo (defect location, size, shunt magnitude, chamber enlargement)

moderate_large_vsd: Medical management of CHF (diuretics, ACEi, calories)
Surgical closure if persistent large shunt with CHF, growth failure, pulmonary HTN

follow_up: Monitor for endocarditis, arrhythmias, aortic regurgitation

instructions: Endocarditis prophylaxis only if residual defect at site of patch/device
Report worsening dyspnea, poor growth (peds), new murmur

diagnoses.name: Ventricular Tachycardia (VT)
initial_tests: Consider coronary angiography if ischemia suspected

long_term: ICD for sustained VT with structural heart disease or cardiac arrest survivors

polymorphic_vt: Avoid antiarrhythmics if due to prolonged QT - treat as Torsades

instructions: Adherence to antiarrhythmic therapy if prescribed
Avoid QT-prolonging meds if history of Torsades
Emergency response plan if ICD shocks occur

diagnoses.name: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome

signs_any: ECG: short PR interval, delta wave, wide QRS

initial_tests: EPS study for risk stratification if symptomatic or high-risk occupation

acute: Stable orthodromic AVRT: vagal maneuvers, adenosine
If pre-excited AF: avoid AV nodal blockers; use procainamide or ibutilide
long_term: Catheter ablation of accessory pathway is definitive
Avoid AV nodal blockers in pre-excited AF

av_nodal_blockers: Do not use β-blockers, CCBs, digoxin, adenosine in pre-excited AF

instructions: Avoid stimulants that may trigger tachyarrhythmia
Consider ablation even if asymptomatic but high-risk occupation/athlete

procedures.name: Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI)
post_care: Dual antiplatelet therapy per stent type

procedures.name: Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)
indications: 3-vessel CAD with LV dysfunction or diabetes

procedures.name: Transcatheter Edge-to-Edge Repair (MitraClip/TEER)
indications: Severe primary or secondary MR in non-surgical candidates

procedures.name: Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (CRT)
indications: EF ≤35% with LBBB and QRS ≥150 ms on GDMT

procedures.name: Left Atrial Appendage Occlusion (LAAO/Watchman)
indications: AF with contraindication to long-term anticoagulation

procedures.name: Electrical Cardioversion (DCCV)
post_care: Anticoagulation if AF/flutter >48h or unknown duration

procedures.name: Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE)
post_care: Surveillance intervals based on lesion severity
